You're in your manager's office for what you thought was a routine check-in. Instead, she closes the door and sits down with a serious expression.

"I have some news," she says. "The senior developer position just opened up unexpectedly. I need to make a recommendation by tomorrow morning."

She pauses. "It's between you, Jordan, and Sam. You all have different strengths." You glance at the team photos on her wall - Jordan who's been [working overtime](/action/overtime-worker) on every project, Sam who [takes initiative](/action/initiative-taker) on new features, and you.

"I'd like your perspective on this," she continues. "Who do you think would be the best fit?"

You take a breath and say, "Honestly, I think I'd be the best fit for this role."

Your manager raises an eyebrow. You continue, "I've been consistent in my work, I understand the codebase well, and I think I'm ready for the leadership responsibilities."

She nods thoughtfully. "That's good self-awareness. But what about [Jordan's dedication](/action/acknowledge-jordan) - those late nights have really moved projects forward. And [Sam's innovations](/action/acknowledge-sam) have impressed the clients."

You feel the weight of [defending your choice](/action/defend-self-recommendation).
